Award.AwardTitle: NSF/DMR/-BSF: Universality and Control of Wave Propagation Inside Random Media
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nontechnical Abstract:
The scattering of waves, whether acoustic, radio or optical, is an inescapable part of our environment. When this environment is disordered the wave can scatter along many different paths and this can impair our ability to communicate or to image or excite electronic circuits. This project will study the propagation of waves through disordered media using a combination of experimental approaches supplanted by theory and simulations. The effort is a collaboration between the PI and the group of Patrick Sebbah at Bar-Ilan University as part of the NSF/DMR-BSF program. The work will focus on developing a universal description of wave propagation in finite random media and will provide an excellent training ground for students. The results of this work will also have a broad impact on a range of interdisciplinary problems in condensed matter physics, acoustics and optics.

Technical Abstract:
The proposed research extends the range of a universal description of wave propagation from the reflected and transmitted wave at the boundaries of disordered media into the interior of the sample and from samples many times thicker than the mean free path to samples so thin that propagation is nearly ballistic. Phenomenological properties of transmission, such as the extrapolation length, upon which the scaling of transmission depends, will be related to universal parameters such as auxiliary localization lengths of different transmission eigenchannels. These parameters depend only on the ratio of sample length and the localization length and the eigenchannel number. An important aspect of the research is finding the relationship between the transmission eigenchannels, modes of waves in the medium, and solutions of a generalized diffusion equation with a position-dependent diffusion coefficient. The relationship between these approaches provides key clues to the control the wave within random media and disordered metamaterials. Such control of the wave inside disordered media provides a path towards improved imaging, resource exploration, local heating within the body, telecommunications, and low-threshold random lasing. The characteristics of a new class of quasi-one dimensional scattering sample, in which the local density of states vanishes in the interior of the sample, is investigated to understand the relationship of the density of states and localization. This provides new pathways to localizing waves and isolating regions from the surrounding environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have moved closer to a comprehensive understanding of the nature of wave propagation inside and through complex systems. Our focus has been on microwave and optical measurements, but the principles discovered apply to any type of wave in inhomogeneous media, including other classical waves, such as sound in the earth’s crust, and quantum mechanical waves, such as electrons in conductors. These studies have applications in biomedical imaging, telecommunications, resource exploration, electronics and photonics. We have explored the intensity profiles of waves inside (1) weakly scattering translucent samples, (2) opaque samples in which the wave randomly diffuses, and (3) strongly scattering samples in which transport is inhibited and the wave is localized in space. In all cases, we find that the spatial distribution of intensity can be expressed in terms of a single parameter, which reduces to the degree to which the range of frequencies which may excite different resonances overlap. We have further expanded the scope of a universal description of wave propagation to systems which are not uniformly random but in which the disorder, and so the scattering strength, varies in space, or in which there are reflectors on the surface or in the interior or the sample, or which absorb or amplify a wave. For each additional factor, a single parameter is added to the capture the nature of propagation. We have also shown that the same general description of propagation holds when the sample contains elements in which the wave cannot propagate and is evanescent.  

 

We have gained a deeper understanding of the universal nature of wave propagation by expressing waves both as a sum of individual resonances of the medium, and also as the sum of the natural channels or transmission eigenchannels by which a medium can be excited. The transmission eigenchannels are obtained from the transmission matrix, whose elements are the transmission coefficients of a wave between all incident and outgoing channels. Since the wave incident upon a sample may be manipulated to correspond to different transmission eigenchannels, transmission through the sample may be controlled once the transmission matrix has been measured. This provides an avenue by which the energy transmitted through and in the interior of the medium can be controlled since the average energy profile excited in different transmission eigenchannels varies systematically with the transmission eigenvalue.

 

We have explored the way statistical description of the resonances of a medium are changed as the coupling of a sample to its surroundings increases and shown that, again, this depends on the overlap of resonances. Significantly, the electromagnetic field profiles of different resonances become more correlated as the sample is opened to its surroundings. This makes it more difficult to selectively excite a a particular resonance of the system, and so to select the dynamic behavior of propagation. We have advanced the concept of the transmission matrix of a particular resonance, and shown that by exciting the sample with the waveform of the resonance on the incident surface, the excitation within that mode is enhanced by a factor equal to the number of incident channels. The number of channels is essentially the cross sectional area of the sample divided by the square of the wavelength. We have further shown that transmission in a particular resonance can greatly exceed unity when the resonances overlaps. However, since the profiles of the field of neighboring resonances are correlated, neighboring resonances are also excited so that the the sum of fields associated with these resonances interfere destructively and the net transmission is reduced well below unity. We have shown that the correlation of the field pattern is in accord with calculations based on the properties of large random matrices whose elements are random numbers, and so is universal.

 

We have demonstrated the transmission time of waves through random systems and shown a deep correspondence between this time, the density of resonances in a medium, and the total energy stored inside the sample summed over all possible excitation channels with and without dissipation or amplification. We show that these quantities may be expressed in terms of a sum over all resonances of the sample. This approach not only gives the dynamical properties of the sample but may provide a path towards analyzing the variation with frequency of the field that is scattered from the sample in terms of the resonances, even when there is strong overlap of the modes.

 

We have emulated the quantum spin Hall effect and the valley degree of freedom of electronic system along the domain wall separating systems with different topology in a metallic metacrystal at microwave frequencies. We find robust propagation of waves launched along the domain wall and the conservation of the valley degree of freedom. Both the spin and valley degrees of freedom can be used to control the flow of electromagnetic radiation.
